Notes: "One might speculate that, with the addition of words, humans acquired the ability to label and ‘hold in memory’ in separate locations distinct phrases such as Allison ate apples and Moira thought otherwise, parallel to the ability to label and separately store in memory the words ate and thought. Once words infiltrated the basic pre-existing syntactic machinery, the combinatory possibilities became open ended."

"Component (i) corresponds to systems for producing, perceiving and learning acoustic sequences, and might itself involve abstract representations that are not strictly sensorimotor, such as stress placement."
